ex.translation[0].definitions[0].definit: someone’s former wife, husband, girlfriend, or boyfriend
ex.translation[0].definitions[0].example: I bumped into my ex in town.
ex.translation[2].definitions[0].definit: used with a price for goods to show from which place the buyer will be responsible for paying for transport of the goods
ex.translation[2].definitions[1].definit: an ex dock, ex quay, or ex wharf price is one where the seller is responsible for taking the goods off the ship in a particular port, and making them available there, but not for transporting them anywhere
ex.translation[2].definitions[2].definit: if a price is ex quay duty paid, it is ex quay with the seller responsible for paying any import taxes
ex.translation[2].definitions[3].definit: if a price is ex quay duties on buyer’s account, it is ex quay with the buyer responsible for paying any import taxes
ex.translation[2].definitions[4].definit: an ex factory or ex works price is one where the seller makes goods available to the buyer at the seller’s factory, and the buyer is responsible for paying for them to be transported to where they are needed
ex.translation[2].definitions[5].definit: an ex ship price is one where the seller will make the goods available on a ship in a particular port, and the buyer is responsible for paying for the goods to be put on land and transported to where they are needed
ex.translation[2].definitions[6].definit: an ex warehouse price is one where the seller makes the goods available at a particular warehouse, and the buyer is responsible for arranging and paying for the goods to be transported to where they are needed
ex.translation[2].definitions[7].definit: used with a share price or bond price to show that the price does not include particular advantages that have been or will soon be available and that might be included, but which instead go the seller
ex.translation[2].definitions[8].definit: an ex all price for shares is one without any of the advantages that have been or will soon be available, for example DIVIDENDs or RIGHTS ISSUEs
ex.translation[2].definitions[9].definit: if shares are sold ex capitalization, the buyer does not have the right to a BONUS ISSUE that has been made
ex.translation[2].definitions[10].defini: if bonds are sold ex coupon or ex interest, the buyer does not have the right to a particular interest payment
ex.translation[2].definitions[10].exampl: Debentures were quoted 6 5/8 points lower at 113 3/8, reflecting the fact the bonds went ex coupon yesterday.
ex.translation[2].definitions[11].defini: if shares or bonds are sold ex dividend, the buyer does not have the right to a particular DIVIDEND payment, or with bonds, to a particular interest payment
ex.translation[2].definitions[11].exampl: Shares in the firm, which issued a profits warning last month, are expected to fall further today when the stock goes ex dividend.
ex.translation[2].definitions[12].defini: when the price of bonds is ex interest, the person who buys them will not receive the next interest payment on them
ex.translation[2].definitions[13].defini: if shares are sold ex rights, the buyer does not have the right to new shares in a particular RIGHTS ISSUE
ex.translation[2].definitions[13].exampl: The shares, traded ex rights, finished SFr17 higher at 1,718.
ex.translation[3].definitions[0].definit: abbreviation for excluding, used to show that an amount is not included
ex.translation[3].definitions[0].example: The desk retails for £349 ex VAT.
